Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Jonathan W. Luk is "Weakly inhomogeneous solutions to the Landau equation and the Boltzmann equation without angular cutoff." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Pennsylvania, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Robert M. Strain.

Performance_Institution.Name: Department of Mathematics, University of Pennsylvania

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focuses on the theory of nonlinear evolutionary partial differential equations arising from mathematical physics. These include the Einstein's equations from general relativity, the Maxwell-Vlasov equation from plasma physics and the compressible Euler's equations from gas dynamics. The project considers what is known as the large data regime for these equations and such that the nonlinearities in the equations cannot be treated perturbatively.

A main part of this project is in the field of general relativity, that is, the study of the Einstein equations. In a sequence of joint works with Rodnianski, we developed a rigorous mathematical theory to study the propagation and interaction of impulsive gravitational waves in general relativity. These are very singular objects associated to the spacetime metric which describes gravitational field. We showed that even though the impulsive gravitational waves are singular, their interaction gives rise to a completely regular wake!

Another central problem in general relativity is to understand the formation of black holes. Despite its fundamental physical importance, there are surprisingly few available results. In fact, the widely expected fact, that trapped surfaces (which is indicative of the presence of black holes) may form dynamically in vacuum by the focusing of gravitational waves, is a result that was only proven in the last decade by Christodoulou! I have worked on various extensions of Christodoulou's result, trying to understand the ``minimal requirement'' on the gravitational waves that guarantees the formation of trapped surfaces: With Klainerman and Rodnianski, we showed that even anisotropic incoming gravitational wave, focused in a small angular sector, can guarantee that trapped surfaces form. With An, we proved that incoming gravitational wave, much milder than that required by Christoudlou, may also cause trapped surfaces to form.

Another fundamental question in general relativity is to describe singularities in the interior of black holes. A celebrated conjecture of Penrose, known as the strong cosmic censorship conjecture (SCC), states that generically ``black hole interiors are singular'' in the sense that the solution admits no suitably regular extensions. However, for the explicit rotating Kerr black holes, the interior of the black hole regions terminate with smooth Cauchy horizons and can be smoothly extended. Thus according to SCC, these interior regions are conjectured to be unstable. In a joint work with Sbierski, we proved a linear instability result for the linear scalar wave equation in the Kerr interior and showed that assuming a natural lower bound in the exterior region, the derivatives of the solutions blow up at the Cauchy horizon. This work is in particular based on ideas on my previous joint work with Oh, in which we treated a similar problem for Reissner-Nordstrom spacetime, and we moreover proved the genericity of the required lower bound in the exterior region.

On the other hand, despite this instability for the derivative, in a recent joint work with Dafermos, we proved that the Kerr Cauchy horizon is at least continuous assuming that the Kerr exterior region is stable. In particular, no singularities form ``before'' the Cauchy horizon. In other words, modulo the conjectural exterior stability, a very strong formulation of SCC turns out to be false!

A second part of the project is the study of the Maxwell-Vlasov equation describing the motion of a collisionless plasma. The basic question regarding this equation is whether solutions remain globally regular. In other words, whether it is possible that for some initial configuration of the plasma, something catastrophic would happen in finite time. While this is not expected, it remains an open problem. With Strain, we proved various results on continuation criteria for the solution, that is, we found quantitative conditions which can guarantee that the solution remains regular.

Finally, in the last part of the project, I studied shock formation in multidimensions in a joint work with Speck, Holzegel and Wong. This in particular applies to the compressible Euler's equations in gas dynamics. The theory of shocks have been well-developed in one spatial dimensions, but remains elusive in higher dimensions. Building on some recent mathematical works by Christodoulou, Christodoulou-Miao, Speck, we showed that a class of plane-symmetric (which can therefore be viewed as one-spatial-dimensional) shock-forming solutions are in fact stable against perturbations which break the symmetry. Moreover, the proof gives a precise description of the shock formation mechanism.

The project also has certain impact beyond the results themselves. Firstly, the very nature of this subject facilitates many fruitful interactions with physicists. In particular, some of the works mentioned above provide the first rigorous mathematical proofs of conjectures arising in physics. Moreover, the project also provides many opportunities for a new generation of graduate students to contribute new ideas and new results. In particular, various sub-projects that are mentioned above, have been further developed and generalized in the thesis works of Gajic, Gleeson, Moortel, Patel.
